\viewkind4\uc1\pard\lang1042\f0\fs20 1 anesthesia:  general  anesthesia is given via an  endotracheal tube 
\par 
\par 2 position
\par the patient is placed in a comfortable supine position with the arm  on the involved side abducted approximately 90 degrees in order to give maximum exposure of the region 
\par 
\par 3 operative preparation :
\par a routine skin prep is performed and the area is draped in a sterile manner
\par 
\par 4 incision and exposure
\par The skin incision was carried down to the subcutaneous fat but no further. Using traction and counter-traction, the upper flap was dissected from the mid axillary region medially to pectoralis major lateral border , superiorly to the subclavian vein , laterally to the lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle, The lower flap was dissected in a similar manner down to the insertion of the pectoralis fascia . Bovie electrocautery was used for the majority of the dissection and hemostasis tying only the large vessels with 2-0 Vicryl. The accessory breast was dissected from the axillary beginning medially and progressing laterally 
\par  Small vessels entering the axillary vein were clipped and divided. One H-VAC 400cc drains were inserted through separate stab incisions below the initial incision and cut to fit.  These were secured to the skin using 2-0 silk, which was Roman-sandaled around the drain.
\par 
\par 
\par }

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg949\deff0\deflang1033\deflangfe1042{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset129 \'b1\'bc\'b8\'b2\'c3\'bc;}}
\viewkind4\uc1\pard\lang1042\f0\fs20 PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Rt breast tumor wide excision and Lt breast partial mastectomy 
\par ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal tube.
\par PROCEDURE: After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the operative suite and placed supine on the operating room table. General endotracheal anesthesia was induced without incident. The patient was prepped and draped in the usual sterile manner. Care was taken to ensure that the arm was placed in a relaxed manner away from the body to facilitate exposure and to avoid nerve injury.
\par An elliptical incision was made to incorporate the previous biopsy site. The skin incision was carried down to the subcutaneous fat but no further. Using traction and counter-traction, the upper flap was dissected from the chest wall medially to medial margin border , superiorly to the clavicle, laterally to the lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle, and superolaterally to the insertion of the pectoralis major muscle. The lower flap was dissected in a similar manner down to the insertion of the pectoralis fascia overlying tumor . Bovie electrocautery was used for the majority of the dissection and hemostasis tying only the large vessels with 2-0 Vicryl. The breast was dissected from the pectoralis muscle beginning medially and progressing laterally removing the pectoralis fascia entirely. Frozen biopsy about margin were taken. 
\par The axillary dissection was then begun by incising the fascia overlying axilla proper allowing visualization of the axillary vein. sentinel Lymph node was taken  The axilla was then cleared of its contents by sharp dissection. Small vessels entering the axillary vein were clipped and divided. The axilla was cleared down to the chest wall, and dissection was continued laterally to the subscapular vein. 
\par One H-VAC 400cc drains were inserted through separate stab incisions below the initial incision and cut to fit.  These were secured to the skin using 2-0 silk, which was Roman-sandaled around the drain.
\par The skin incision was approximated with suture. A dressing was applied. The drains were placed on "grenade" suction. All surgical counts were reported as correct.
\par Having tolerated the procedure well, the patient was subsequently extubated and taken to the recovery room in good and stable condition
\par 
\par }

\viewkind4\uc1\pard\lang1042\f0\fs20 Findings of operation: The mass was identified with preop. colonoscopic marking.
\par 
\par Procedures of operation
\par  Under the general anesthesia,the patient was laid on the lithotomy position.
\par  The routine drapping was done.
\par  5 trocar was inserted in the routine manner.
\par  Full-through examination was performed.
\par  Lt. colic a. & v. were ligated.
\par      => full Lt. colon ~ sigmoid => dissected.
\par  Sigmoid colon was divided with endo-GIA
\par  LLQ  port was opened & wound protector was inserted.
\par  The sigmoid colon was resected & purse-string suture was done & envil was inserted.
\par  EEA was applied & anastomotic site was checked.
\par  H-vac drain was inserted.
\par  The operative wound was closed.

omt24cmt:
{\rtf1\fbidis\ansi\ansicpg949\deff0\deflang1033\deflangfe1042{\fonttbl{\f0\fmodern\fprq2\fcharset129 \'b8\'bc\'c0\'ba \'b0\'ed\'b5\'f1;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset0 Times New Roman;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset129 \'b1\'bc\'b8\'b2\'c3\'bc;}}
\viewkind4\uc1\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\sa200\sl276\slmult1\qj\kerning2\f0\fs20 The patient is placed in a lateral decubitus position with the arm in abduction to open the axillary hollow Before any incision  the area to be undermined should be copiously infiltrated with physiologic saline(about 400cc)The skin paddle is incised by a single cut down to the fascia superficialis in order to preserve the subcutaneous blood supply Dissection then follows the deep aspect of the fascia superficialis, taking care to leave the deep fat on the muscle(zone2) Sparing of the fascia superficialis best preserves the dorsal cutaneous blood supply and the undermined area is of homogenous thickness The upper part of the undermined area reaches the inferior angle of the scapular.In the internal part, the fascia superficialis is undermined up to the trapezius, whose lower lateral margin is exposed along all its length The whole area of fatty tissue between the superior border of the latissimus dorsi, the trapezius, and the upper limit of undermining forms the surface of the scapular hinger flap (zone 3)To elevate the flap, first its superior horizontal margin is incised : then the flap is raised gradually by starting dissection in the extension of the lateral margin of the trapezius The scapular syssarcosis is then dissected When the medical margin of the teres major is reached, the cutaneous prolongation of the circumflex scapular pedicle should be carefully ligated Laterally the hinger flap is dissected up to the medial margin of the lattisimus dorsi In its lower medial part the rhomboid muscle should be carefully preserved and the flap is raised like a hinge on the cranial marign of the latissimus dorsi muscle until the point of the scapular is freed In the lower part, undermining should be a little wider than in the area of latissimus dorsi to make it easier to release the muscle later The lower limit lies a little above the iliac crest in order to harvest fat from the love handles(zone 5)In the medial part, the cutaneous perforators of the intercostal posterior arteries that lie above the transverse processes mark the limitThe whole length of the trapezius must be clearly identified to separate it from the paradorsal insertion of the lattisimus dorsi In the lateral part dissection begins a few centimeters forward of the anterior margin of the lattismus dorsi in order to harvest fat in zone4 The muscle is then separated at a deep level from the serratus anterior by starting at about 15cm from the axilla. Submuscular undermining is continued by harvesting the deep fat(zone6) and by carefully ligating or coagulating the accessory pedicles When the lattimus dorsi is completely undermined its distal part is transected, from the deep part t

{\rtf1\fbidis\ansi\ansicpg949\deff0\deflang1033\deflangfe1042{\fonttbl{\f0\fmodern\fprq2\fcharset129 \'b8\'bc\'c0\'ba \'b0\'ed\'b5\'f1;}{\f1\froman\fprq2\fcharset0 Times New Roman;}{\f2\fnil\fcharset129 \'b1\'bc\'b8\'b2\'c3\'bc;}}
\viewkind4\uc1\pard\ltrpar\nowidctlpar\sa200\sl276\slmult1\qj\kerning2\f0\fs20 Detail of Procedure
\par A typical placement for access ports is shown at the umbilicus , left lower quadrant , and lower midline . As in most laparoscopic procedures, some form of triangulation is employed, with the longest and widest angle given to the operating ports and instruments. The videoscopic port is created first . ( Although some use an initial inflation of the abdomen with a Veress needle, most general surgeons employ the open Hasson technique. The surgeon may enter at the superior or inferior margin of the umbilicus with either a vertical or semicircular transverse incision . After the Haason port is placed and secured with the stay sutures, the abdomen is inflated with CO2. The surgeon sets the maximum gas pressure(<15mmHg) and flow rate while he or she monitors the actual intraabdominal pressure and the total volumn of gas insufflated . the abdomen then enlarges and becomes tympanic
\par The videoscope is attaced to the telescopic instrument, which may be straight(zero degress) or angled. The system is white balanced and the focus adjusted. After the optical end of the instrument has been cleaned with antifog solution, it is introduced down the Hasson port. A careful visualization of all four quadrants of the abdomen is performed and a record is made of all normal and abnormal findings
\par Under direct vision with the videoscope, two additional 5mm ports are put into the abdomen. One is in the left lower quadrant and is placed lateral to the rectus muscle with its epigastric vessels. The light of the videoscope is used to transilluminate the abdominal wall at the proposed site so as to avoid trocar placement through vessels in the oblique muscles. (The surgeon infiltrates the 5mm site with local anesthesia) this infiltrating needle can be advanced through the abdominal wall and the videoscope will see the needle enter the anticipated site for this port. A 5mm skin incision is made and the subcutaneous tissue dilated with a small hemostat down to the level of the fascia. The 5mm port is placed through the abdominal wall while the surgeon views the safe entrance of the pointed trocar into the intraperitoneal space. The third port is placed through the midline linea alba in a suprapubic position so as to avoid the bladder, which has been  decompressed with a Foley catheter. The strategy for a widely spread (hand's breadth) triangular pattern of port placement now become apparent as the three instruments compete for room to maneuver. 
\par The patient is placed in the Trendelenburg  position and the right side of the operating table may be elevated using gravity to hold the small bowel away from the right lower quadrant. (If
omt24cmtb:
a normal appendix is found, a search for other inflammatory processes is begun. Tubo-ovarian diseases, inflammatory bowel disease, and Meckel's diverticulitis are most commonly found.) The appendix and its mesentery must be clearly visualized. (The position of the appendix is quite variable, and it may be covered with peritoneum or even the cecum. Safe opening of any peritoneal covering or the equivalent of the lateral line of Toldt along the cecum may require placement of an additional operating port . If the surgeon cannot obtain complete visualization of the appendix, mesoappendix, and base of the cecum for a safe transection, the operation is coverted to an open procedure)
\par Laparoscopic removal begins with a splaying out of the mesoappendix using a grasping forceps upon the mesentery . the inflamed tip of the appendix is not grasped, as this could cause it to rupture. The surgeon opens through the mesentery at the base of the appendix using a dissecting instrument. If maneuvering of the appendix and its mesentery is difficult using the grasping forceps, some surgeons prefer to lasso the inflamed end of the appendix with a loop suture that is applied snugly. The cut end of this suture may be grasped more securely with the maneuvering forceps. The mesoappendix is divied in one or more transection using an endoscopic vasucular stapling instrument that is passed through the large Hasson port. This assumens that a 5mm videoscope is available for use through the left lower quadrant port. Otherwise the left lower quadrant port is enlarged to 10mm as both the videoscope and endoscopic vascular stapler require  large ports. The base of the appendix is divied with the endoscopic cutting linear stapler. An important maneuver with any division using this staple is to rotate it about 180 degresss, so as to visualize the entire length and the contents within its jaws . this rotation should also be done during the stapling of the mesoappendix. 
\par A small minimally inflamed appendix can be removed safely through the shaft of a 10mm port. Most surgeon place an enlarged or suppurative appendix into a plastic bag for removal through the abdominal wall. This lessens the chance of infection at the surgical site. The appendiceal stump and stapled mesoappendix are inspected for security and hemostasis. The area is lavaged with the suction irrigation and a regional inspection is made to verify the integrity of the cecum and small bowel. Each of the 5mm port is removed under direct vision with the videoscope to make sure that there are no bleeding abdominal wall vessels. 
\par Closure 
\par The abdomen is decompressed and the Hasson port removed. Routinely only the 10mm port sites require facial closure . Scarpa's fascia and the subcutaneous fat are not closed. The skin is approximated with fine  #  absorbable sutures 
\par Adhesive skin strips and small dry sterile dressing are applied 
\par   \f1 
\par \pard\ltrpar\lang1042\kerning0\f2\fs20 
\par }

omt24cmt:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg949\deff0\deflang1033\deflangfe1042{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset129 \'b1\'bc\'b8\'b2\'c3\'bc;}}
\viewkind4\uc1\pard\lang1042\f0\fs20 circumareolar incision  was made to incorporate the nipple-areolar complex and the previous biopsy site. The skin incision was carried down to the subcutaneous fat but no further. Using traction and counter-traction, the upper flap was dissected from the chest wall medially to the medial margin, superiorly to superior margin, laterally to the lateral margin , and superolaterally to the insertion of the pectoralis major muscle. The lower flap was dissected in a similar manner down to the insertion of the pectoralis fascia overlying the fifth rib medially and laterally out to the latissimus dorsi. Bovie electrocautery was used for the majority of the dissection and hemostasis tying only the large vessels with 2-0 Vicryl. The breast was dissected from the pectoralis muscle beginning medially and progressing laterally removing the pectoralis fascia entirely. Once the lateral border of the pectoralis major muscle was identified, the pectoralis muscle was retracted medially and the interpectoral fat was removed with the specimen.
\par sentinel LN biopsy  was then begun by incising the fascia overlying axilla proper allowing visualization of the axillary vein. The highest point of axillary dissection was then marked with a long stitch for identification by the surgical pathologist. The axilla was then cleared of its contents by sharp dissection. Small vessels entering the axillary vein were clipped and divided. The axilla was cleared down to the chest wall, and dissection was continued laterally to the subscapular vein. The long thoracic nerve was cleared identified lying against the chest and was carefully preserved. The long thoracic nerve represented the posterior most aspect of the dissection. 
\par Two H-VAC 400cc  drains were inserted through separate stab incisions below the initial incision and cut to fit. The most posterior of the2 was directed into the axilla and the other directed anteriorly across the pectoralis major. These were secured to the skin using 2-0 silk, which was Roman-sandaled around the drain.
\par The skin incision was approximated with Nylon#5 . A dressing was applied. H-VAC 200cc were placed . All surgical counts were reported as correct.
\par Having tolerated the procedure well, the patient was subsequently extubated and taken to the recovery room in good and stable condition
\par 
\par }

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg949\deff0\deflang1033\deflangfe1042{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset129 \'b1\'bc\'b8\'b2\'c3\'bc;}}
\viewkind4\uc1\pard\lang1042\f0\fs20 1 anesthesia: MAC anesthesia is given via an  EG tube 
\par 
\par 2 position
\par the patient is placed in a comfortable supine position with the arm  on the involved side abducted approximately 90 degrees in order to give maximum exposure of the region 
\par 
\par 3 operative preparation :
\par keep the hooked wire in microcalcification under mammogram
\par a routine skin prep is performed and the area is draped in a sterile manner
\par 
\par 4 incision and exposure
\par  A suitable site for skin puncture some distance away from the lesion is chosen according to the position of the lesion in the breast and the Mammotome and ultrasound probe orientations preferred by the operator. Local anaesthetic is infiltrated into the skin and subcutaneous tissues, and a small skin incision no larger than the tip of the probe is made in the skin. Further local anaesthetic is then injected into the deeper tissue using a spinal or similar needle positioned under direct ultrasonic visualisation, infiltrating along the planned Mammotome track and around the lesion. Ten millilitres of 1% or 2% Xylocaine with 1 in 200 000 adrenaline is usually adequate. 
\par 
\par The probe is inserted in 'positioning' mode, with the aperture closed. A blade on the tip of 8-gauge probe helps it to pass cleanly through the tissues. The probe is generally positioned so that the aperture (which can be readily identified on ultrasound, even in the closed position) lies immediately behind the lesion, although some larger lesions may be more easily removed by being transfixed by the probe. The system is then switched to 'sampling' mode, and lesion removal can begin. If the probe is correctly positioned posterior to the lesion, the mass can be seen being sucked into the specimen aperture as the 'forward' button l is depressed.
\par 
\par Progress of lesion removal is usually well seen on ultrasound, although occasionally completeness of removal can be difficult to assess due to the presence of air and/or blood in the cavity.This is done by incrementally rotating the holster between samplings when the probe aperture is closed. In addition, elevation of the probe as the lesion is progressively removed may help the remaining part of the lesion to enter the aperture. 
\par 
\par The number of cores required to obtain complete lesion removal is very variable, depending on the size of the lesion, the gauge of probe used and the position of the probe relative to the lesion.
\par 
\par check the specimen mammogram 
\par remained tumor rechecked 
\par 
\par 
\par Following withdrawal of the probe, firm pressure is applied for several minutes to the area of tissue removal A pressure dressing is then applied. 
\par 
\par the epidermis is approximated with nylon #5 
\par the skin is cleaned dired and apply a simple gauze dress

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg949\deff0\deflang1033\deflangfe1042{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset129 \'b1\'bc\'b8\'b2;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset129 \'b1\'bc\'b8\'b2\'c3\'bc;}}
\viewkind4\uc1\pard\lang1042\f0\fs20 1 anesthesia: MAC anesthesia is given via an  EG tube

\par the patient is placed in a comfortable supine position with the arm  on the involved side abducted approximately 90 degrees in order to give maximum exposure of the region 
\par 
\par 3 operative preparation :
\par a routine skin prep is performed and the area is draped in a sterile manner
\par 
\par 4 incision and exposure
\par  A suitable site for skin puncture some distance away from the lesion is chosen according to the position of the lesion in the breast and the Mammotome and ultrasound probe orientations preferred by the operator. Local anaesthetic is infiltrated into the skin and subcutaneous tissues, and a small skin incision no larger than the tip of the probe is made in the skin. Further local anaesthetic is then injected into the deeper tissue using a spinal or similar needle positioned under direct ultrasonic visualisation, infiltrating along the planned Mammotome track and around the lesion. Ten millilitres of 1% or 2% Xylocaine with 1 in 200 000 adrenaline is usually adequate. 
\par 
\par The probe is inserted in \lquote positioning\rquote  mode, with the aperture closed. A blade on the tip of 8-gauge probe helps it to pass cleanly through the tissues. The probe is generally positioned so that the aperture (which can be readily identified on ultrasound, even in the closed position) lies immediately behind the lesion, although some larger lesions may be more easily removed by being transfixed by the probe. The system is then switched to \lquote sampling\rquote  mode, and lesion removal can begin. If the probe is correctly positioned posterior to the lesion, the mass can be seen being sucked into the specimen aperture as the \lquote forward\rquote  button l is depressed.
\par 
\par Progress of lesion removal is usually well seen on ultrasound, although occasionally completeness of removal can be difficult to assess due to the presence of air and/or blood in the cavity.This is done by incrementally rotating the holster between samplings when the probe aperture is closed. In addition, elevation of the probe as the lesion is progressively removed may help the remaining part of the lesion to enter the aperture. 
\par 
\par The number of cores required to obtain complete lesion removal is very variable, depending on the size of the lesion, the gauge of probe used and the position of the probe relative to the lesion.
\par 
\par Following withdrawal of the probe, firm pressure is applied for several minutes to the area of tissue removal A pressure dressing is then applied. 
\par 
\par the epidermis is approximated with nylon #5 
\par the skin is cleaned dired and apply a simple gauze dressing and a surgical bra
\par 
\par \f1 
\par 
\par }

{\rtf1\fbidis\ansi\ansicpg949\deff0\deflang1033\deflangfe1042{\fonttbl{\f0\fmodern\fprq2\fcharset129 \'b1\'bc\'b8\'b2;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset129 \'b1\'bc\'b8\'b2\'c3\'bc;}}
\viewkind4\uc1\pard\ltrpar\sb100\sa100\b\f0\fs24 PROCEDURE PERFORMED: \b0 Modified radical mastectomy.
\par \b ANESTHESIA: \b0 General endotracheal tube.
\par \b PROCEDURE: \b0 After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the operative suite and placed supine on the operating room table. General endotracheal anesthesia was induced without incident. The patient was prepped and draped in the usual sterile manner. Care was taken to ensure that the arm was placed in a relaxed manner away from the body to facilitate exposure and to avoid nerve injury.
\par An elliptical incision was made to incorporate the nipple-areolar complex and the previous biopsy site. The skin incision was carried down to the subcutaneous fat but no further. Using traction and counter-traction, the upper flap was dissected from the chest wall medially to the sternal border, superiorly to the clavicle, laterally to the anterior border of the latissimus dorsi muscle, and superolaterally to the insertion of the pectoralis major muscle. The lower flap was dissected in a similar manner down to the insertion of the pectoralis fascia overlying the fifth rib medially and laterally out to the latissimus dorsi. Bovie electrocautery was used for the majority of the dissection and hemostasis tying only the large vessels with 2-0 Vicryl. The breast was dissected from the pectoralis muscle beginning medially and progressing laterally removing the pectoralis fascia entirely. Once the lateral border of the pectoralis major muscle was identified, the pectoralis muscle was retracted medially and the interpectoral fat was removed with the specimen.
\par The axillary dissection was then begun by incising the fascia overlying axilla proper allowing visualization of the axillary vein. The highest point of axillary dissection was then marked with a long stitch for identification by the surgical pathologist. The axilla was then cleared of its contents by sharp dissection. Small vessels entering the axillary vein were clipped and divided. The axilla was cleared down to the chest wall, and dissection was continued laterally to the subscapular vein. The long thoracic nerve was cleared identified lying against the chest and was carefully preserved. The long thoracic nerve represented the posterior most aspect of the dissection. As the axillary contents were dissected in the posterolateral axilla, the thoracodorsal nerve was identified and carefully preserved. The dissection continued caudally until the entire specimen was freed and delivered from the operative field. Copious water lavage was used to remove any debris, and hemostasis was obtained with Bovie electrocautery.
\par Two Jackson-Pratt drains were inserted through separate stab incisions below the initial incision and cut to fit. The most posterior of the
omt24cmtb:
2 was directed into the axilla and the other directed anteriorly across the pectoralis major. These were secured to the skin using 2-0 silk, which was Roman-sandaled around the drain.
\par The skin incision was approximated with skin staples. A dressing was applied. The drains were placed on "grenade" suction. All surgical counts were reported as correct.
\par Having tolerated the procedure well, the patient was subsequently extubated and taken to the recovery room in good and stable condition
\par \pard\ltrpar\lang1042\f1\fs20 
\par }

\par The mass was well-capsulated.
\par 
\par Procedures of operation:
\par  1) Under the general anesthesia, the patient was laid in the prone position.
\par  2) The routine drapping was performed.
\par  3) Transverse incision was made.
\par  4) THe mass was removed.

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg949\deff0\deflang1033\deflangfe1042{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset129 \'b1\'bc\'b8\'b2\'c3\'bc;}}
\viewkind4\uc1\pard\lang1042\f0\fs20 surgical procedure
\par the skin incision is made along the V shaped markings 
\par on both sides it is carried 1.0cm ~1.5cm into the lower portion of the new areolar site
\par for subcutaneous dissection of the lower portion of the gland, the skin margins are clamped with forceps to allow superficia dissection
\par under tension, similar to a subcutaneous mastectomy subcutaneous dissection extends over both inferior quadrants into the inframammary fold
\par Here the tissue is incised down to the muscle on the chest wall
\par next the superiorly based nipple pedicle is elevated After the skin incision a 2cm thick layer of the inferior part of the nipple flap is clamped with two ring forceps 
\par dissection then proceeds vertically aroud the entire flap , slightly beveling away from the flap 
\par the flap is the elevated from the parenchyma obliquely as far as the upper margin of the areolar 
\par the next step involves dissecting the central tissue of the gland off the chest wall or pectoralis muscle  subglandular dissection begins at the level of the inframammary fold 
\par after the tough connective tissue attachment of the glandular tissue has been cut at the lateral border of the pectoralis muscle dissection continues bluntly up to about the third intercostal space 
\par the gland is raised to its superior margin over 6~8cm wide central tunnel 
\par central dissection allows the breast to move superiorly as a type of overcorrection 
\par Excess parenchyma is mainly removed from the central and inferior portions of the breast 
\par Starting at the cutaneous incision line the medial and lateral parenchyma is incised down to the chest wall 
\par this also forms the two lateral pillars , which will be approximated later in the operation 
\par depending on the extent of reduction necessary, the parenchyma may also be resected posteriorly from the lateral pillars 
\par the lateral pillars must be shortened if they exceed 6~7cm in length 
\par after sufficient hemostasis the mastopexy suture is placed. Slowly absorbing suture material is used 
\par deep suture is placed through the pectoralis muscle at the upper border of the breast parenchyma and opposite it at the upper limit of the 
\par parenchyma excision, usually at the level of the superior margin of the areola, 
\par the nipple arolar complex is moved superiorly by affixing the upper border of the areolar with absorbable 4.0 suture material at the upper border of the de epithelized skin
\par the next step, approximation of the breast pillars, is another important part of achieving proper breast contour and shape 
\par absorbable 3 sutures are placed through the breast pillars the sutures are placed through the parenchyma and pulled through the subcutaneous fatty tissue
\par the desired bresat breast shape can be achie
omt24cmtb:
ved by adjusting tension and the threads 
\par preliminary approximation of the skin margins can reveal where subcutaneous dissection may still be needed 
\par tightening of the skin has now visibly raised the breast and thus the inframmary flol 
\par the lower limit of the vertical skin incision should therefore also be fixed to the lower border of the breast 
\par Drains are placed inferolaterally the second subdermal suture is then placed at the lower boder of the areola
\par the wound is then closed and excess skin tightened finally an intracutaneous suture with absrobable 4 suture material is placed 
\par afterward the areolar is sutured in layes with suddermal and intracutaneous sutures
\par A sterile elastic pressure bandage is applied aroud the chest 
\par }

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg949\deff0\deflang1033\deflangfe1042{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset129 \'b1\'bc\'b8\'b2\'c3\'bc;}}
\viewkind4\uc1\pard\lang1042\f0\fs20 marking the inframmary approach
\par midline and inframammary fold
\par raising the arms stimulates the higher position of the nipple after augmentation 
\par 1) skin incision  
\par 2) exposure of the lateral border of the pectoralis muscle
\par 3) subglandular dissection along the planned muscle incision to alongside the sternum
\par 4) muscle transection using electrocautery scissors
\par 5) after transecting the muscle
\par 6) blunt dissection laterally (elevating the pectoralis major off the pectoralis minor ) 
\par   the remainder is sharply dissected
\par 7) placement of the definitive implant
\par 8) after placing a three point suture 
\par 9) three point fixation in the inframammary fold 
\par the first suture at the level of the skin incision in the chest wall musculature
\par 10) second and third sutures in the Scarpa fascia
\par the skin is incised and the incison is deepened vertically through the subcutaneous tissue to the chest wall.The Scapa fascia can already be identified at this stage. the dissection is still too inferior.the gland is dissected superioly over a distance of 3~4cm off the underlying chest wall or musclature (external oblique , serratus anterior, pectoralis major) this provides good visualization of the orgin of the pectoralis major at the  fifth and sixth ribs. the subglandular dissction carried medially to alongside the sternum is sharp, while the loose connective tissue overlying the lateral portion of the serratus anterior may be bluntly dissected. perforating vessels between the gland and muscle are coagulated after the inferior portion of the pectoralis major has been exposed, it is divide wih electrocautery , proceeding from its lateral margin nearly to the sternum. the stumps of the muscle fibers must be thoroughly coagulated. the pectoral muscle is elervated with a Langenbeck retractor and remaining muscle fibers arising from the chest wall are divided. digital separation of the pectralis major and minor is the best way to avoid inadvertent division of pectoralis minor muscle fibers. sharp dissection is done medially dissection superiorly can be done using a blunt technique
\par }
